page.title: First Nations Pandemic Response
page.description: The page for The Meeting House First Nations Pandemic Response in partnership with MCC Canada.

image1.alt: Man sharing First Nations peace practices and rituals with a group.

content.text1: Lack of access to clean water, overcrowded households, and limited medical care have made remote First Nations communities especially vulnerable to the COVID-19 pandemic. At the request of over a dozen First Nations communities in Ontario, we are raising $24,000 to purchase kits of sanitary items to help slow the spread of the virus.
content.text2: *Donations will be made to Mennonite Central Committee directly

content.text1: We’re partnering with the Mushkegowuk Council, the Windigo First Nation Council, and Mennonite Central Committee (MCC) who have determined the items in the kits. The two councils will work with MCC to distribute the kits to the most vulnerable households among 14 remote First Nations communities and three Indigenous organizations in Timmins. Our partners estimate that over 15,000 people will benefit from this initiative.

image1.alt: A women and her baby recieve a peacemakers relief kit from an Aid Worker in Jordan.

content.text1: By giving $10 for a kit, we are partnering with First Nations leaders to equip their own communities. They have requested that we raise $24,000 in order to make 2,400 kits.

image1.alt: A teeange boy is volunteering for the peacemakers campaign by placing relief kit items into large bucket for shipping.

content.text1: As a church, we’ve been exploring what it means to work toward reconciliation between Indigenous and settler communities. Through partnership this season, ensuring that vulnerable families have access to sanitary items is a tangible way for us to pursue this together.

image1.alt: Young girl shares a picture she drew of the violence she experienced in Syria.
Volunteers working together to pack Peacemakers relief kits.

list.question: Can I only give online?
answer: Yes. Donations are made to Mennonite Central Committee directly and can be received online through the giving portal above.

list.question: Will I receive a tax receipt?
answer: Yes. Donations over $10 will be issued a tax receipt by Mennonite Central Committee. Note that you will not receieve a tax receipt from The Meeting House.

list.question: Which First Nations communities will receive the kits?
answer: Mushkegowuk Council (7): Weenisk, Attawapiskat, Fort Albany, Kashechewan, Moose Cree, Mocreebec First Nations, and the town of Moosonee.
Windigo First Nation Council (7): Bearskin Lake, Cat Lake, Koocheching, North Caribou, Sachigo, Slate Falls, and Whitewater First Nations.
Timmins Urban Organizations: Missiway Health Centre, the Timmins Native Friendship Centre, and the MCC Indigenous Neighbours office.

list.question: What are the items in the kits?
answer: MCC will bulk purchase the items in the kit (please do not purchase them yourselves). The kits will include a hand towel, a face cloth, hand sanitizer, a face mask, a laundry soap bar, and two bars of soap.

list.question: Can I purchase the items in the kit myself?
answer: No. We want to play our part in limiting the spread of COVID-19, which is why we don’t want to encourage our community to leave their homes to purchase the kits. Additionally, by bulk ordering items in the kits, our partners will be able to distribute the kits sooner.

list.question: What happens if we surpass our goal?
answer: This would be awesome! Any additional funds would be given to MCC’s Indigenous Neighbours program to be used to address the ongoing needs of their First Nations communities in Ontario.

list.question: What is the Mushkegowuk Council & Windigo First Nation Council?
answer: The Mushkegowuk Council & Windigo First Nation Council are non-profit regional chiefs' councils representing two groups of First Nations communities in northern Ontario, Canada. Each council provides advisory services and program delivery to its member nations.

list.question: Why partner with MCC?
answer: We are proud to be partnering with Mennonite Central Committee as they come alongside locally directed projects around the globe and here in Canada. MCC also has a strong relationship with many First Nations communities in Ontario and has developed a positive reputation among these communities.

MCC Canada has demonstrated commitment to a high level of transparency, accountability, and integrity. They are a member of the Canadian Council of Christian Charities (CCCC) and the Better Business Bureau, which have standards for fundraising as well as managing and reporting finances. In 2019, MCC was listed on Charity Intelligence Canada’s Top 10 International Impact Charities.
